dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dormitory of the section gang. The men are through fo lounging on their bunkbeds. DUFF ANDERSON plays checkers bottle tops as pieces. Duff makes the winning move and Fr turns over the board. He saunters over to JOCKO, who is s mirror. Frankie watches him with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you sure one ugly cat! He takes the cigarettes Jocko has rolled, sailor-style, i his T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you guys buy your own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Oughta give up smoking, Jocko. He stops in front of an older man, who is writing a lette

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer we got on this stretch, Riddick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five weeks, maybe six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, what a dump. He circles restlessly past two cardplayers back to Duff, fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gettin' all pretty for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  Why don't you relax, Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: RAILROAD TRACK
dialogues.text: Duff, Frankie, and Jocko are riding a track-car, powered into the nearest town. The sun is setting. A church bell

dialogues.speaker: POOL HALL
dialogues.text: Jocko, a cigar in his mouth, is playing a pinball machine stand at the bar. They are joined by DORIS , a sad-lookin skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to buy me a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornfully)  What's the matter, Doris? Business bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody givin' it away free, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna buy me a beer, Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See Duff. He's the money man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you say, Duff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender)  Give her a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Duff. You' a nice guy. Not like Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Doris - you'd make some guy a swell  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so, Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, you got steady work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit ridin' her, Frankie. The bartender serves her a bottle of beer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't ridin' her. Wouldn't ride her on a bet. Duff pays for the beer and turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where' you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where' you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Round town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so hot 'round town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  Take it easy, Frankie. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wanna fish you outa no jailhouse. STREET (Night) Duff is walking along the deserted street in the black pa Music from the pool hall fades and we pick up the strains from a nearby church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir is singing "Precious Lord." The women are spiri congregation in the small wooden building is alive to the Duff appears in the open doorway and stops to listen. When the song ends, REVEREND DAWSON rises from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to see this meeting off to a good  start. Now we'll take a break and then come back  to hear from our distinguished guest - Reverend  Butler of the Morgan Street Baptist Church in  Birmingham. See you all in a little while. Reverend Butler compliments him on the choir.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH YARD
dialogues.text: Long tables laden with food are lit by strings of lightbu gospel piano from inside the church. A smiling middle-aged woman has taken Duff in tow and lea young woman (JOSIE), who is serving food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie - this is Brother Anderson. Now you give  him some of that good food. He's a fine young  man.  (on her way)  Ain't it a wonderful meetin'?! Duff studies Josie with a smile. She is clearly middle cl food on a paper plate, she glances at him - matching his with her own. She hands him the plate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ma'am. That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be new in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  I'll have me some of that punch there, too. She serves the punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't seen you around, have I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm new in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unwilling to give up)  You working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. On the section gang. He is sure that this will put a stop to her curiosity. It

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested)  Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work around town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went to college, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Birmingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? That's my home town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your folks live there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. My mother's dead. (after a moment) You goin' back inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Never had much use for hell-howlers. You  goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)  My father's the preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning)  Oh yeah? Well, I guess you got no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit tentatively)  Look, I don't know what you been told 'bout  section gangs, but how 'bout seein' me sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a non-committal smile)  Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The visiting revival preacher is in full swing, preaching congregation of women is in a state of high excitement. J of it, though she sits in their midst. Duff has been standing in the doorway. He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff walks away, past a shack. The singing fades. A dog b BUNK CAR (Night)  Duff, Frankie, Jocko, and an older man (POP) are playing for his turn, Jocko catches a fly and sneaks a look at Fr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a lousy hand, Frankie. Frankie throws down the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I quit. He gets up. At loose ends, he picks up an old Flit-gun an Duff, who is polishing his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got nothin' on your mind but your hair,  Frankie. How 'bout your car, Riddick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you won't like that back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, why 'you messin' around with a gal like  that? You won't get no place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, they're all after the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. All a colored woman wants is your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you know about women, Pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got married to one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I didn't know you was married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Got a sixteen-year-old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?  (to Duff)  Think you're gonna make it with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get her drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Riddick)  How 'bout the key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet she's easy jam. DAWSON DINING ROOM (Night) A middle-class tableau. Dinner is over. Reverend Dawson i Josie, dressed for an evening out, sits across from her s looking at her with pursed lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you pay no mind to my feelings, but  d'you think it's right for you to go out with  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm twenty-six years old, Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you ought to tell her, Frank. Reverend Dawson has no stomach for confrontations, but tu dutifully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we have a position in town, Josie. You  have to remember that. There're lots of other  young men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think your mother would have approved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's just one thing you can be looking  for in a man like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that's what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush your mouth, child. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving the table)  Good night, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD HOUSE
dialogues.text: On the dimly lit, smoke-hung floor a large crowd is danci a great time. When the music ends, she and Duff return to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pretty good for a preacher's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you expect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, baby, I can't figure you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why d'you come out with me? You slummin' or  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what you doin' with a cat like me in a joint  like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think much of yourself, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (put off)  Well, that's a funny thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep asking me why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you keep not answerin', too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like a place with lots of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about another beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on - you can have one! His attention is drawn by something off screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Frankie and Jocko swagger toward them, beer in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it ain't Duff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin'? (to Josie; with  a bit of a leer) Hi there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if we sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We was just leavin', fellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, Jocko. The man's got homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving)  See you, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, see you in hell. Frankie follows Jocko out of the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must work on the section gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they seem just like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, baby, I bet you think we got tails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen)  We do! Frankie and Jocko have occupied the adjoining table and a Duff gets up, camouflaging his irritation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, baby. He ushers Josie out. Frankie looks after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School teacher! My nappy head! INT. RIDDICK'S OLD CONVERTIBLE (Night) Duff has parked on a country road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's hard working on the road like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn few places you can make eighty bucks a  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you're kind of cut off, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine with me. Keeps me out of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't get on so well most places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. That beer made me dizzy. Duff is looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a lovely face, kid. Ain't too often I  get to meet a girl like you. Hell-- He kisses her, but releases her very quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, how many times' you been kissed? Josie takes a moment to collect herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see now - not counting tonight ...  must be about twenty-eight times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  You got a problem all right. Someone moves in back of her. A white man in his early tw from the dark and looks down at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)  Hi. The voice of a second white man calls from off screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They doin' anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back)  Nah, nothin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened)  Don't Duff--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, man! The second white man joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's goin' on? He shines his flashlight into Duff's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut that out! The white man shines the flashlight across Josie's breast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very tense)  I said: Cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start no trouble, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go! That's the preacher's girl. Mess with  him and you got old man Johnson on your back.  Come on. The white men leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. We see that he has a knife in his hand. He closes and poc The white men drive off, whooping and beating on the side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sound human, do they? INT. MOVING CAR (Night) Duff is driving through the center of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you stay 'round here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my mother was the only good teacher the  colored school ever had. Nobody bothers with  those kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you come back, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to see any change. But I'm going to  stay. Another year, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got more guts than me, baby. It's a no-good  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than it used to be. Eight years ago  they still had a lynching here. They tied a man  to a car and dragged him to death. My father  knew who did it, but he didn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared, huh? The car pulls up in front of the Dawson house and Duff pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good night, baby. He is about to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get it. (with a laugh) Yeah, I can see your old man with a shot-gun  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I would like to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would, huh? If I was you, baby - I wouldn't  go 'round stickin' out my jugular vein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You almost got into trouble back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)  I wouldn't have let you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, baby, I'm not in the third grade. Well,  look - what' we gonna do next time -- have a  nice long chat in the parlor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, and then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, either we're gonna hit the hay or get  married. Now you don't want to hit the hay, and  I don' want to get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have some very primitive ideas, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively)  All right, so I'm primitive. So what d'you want  with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Duff - most of the men I know - they're  kind of sad. When I met you the other day I had  a feeling that you're different. That's why I  went out with you. I thought we might have  something to say to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, baby, I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Duff. She gets out of the car and starts toward the house. He looks after her, then drives away.

dialogues.speaker: OPEN FIELD
dialogues.text: The section hands are hunting rabbits, scaring them up ou and then clubbing them with sticks that have a heavy bolt Jocko is fishing from a trestle. Pop fries skinned rabbit is whittling.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: The grade school children, all black, are writing at thei The end-of-school bell rings and one of the boys jumps up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished, Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not. Wait till class is dismissed. She walks over to close the window. In the yard below, Duff is sitting on one of the swings. Josie smiles and turns to the kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Class dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus crowded with noisy kids pulls away to reveal the ya are sitting on two swings side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first it was real strange. Hell, Japan is a  long ways from Alabama. Really got under my  skin, though. Almost didn't come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. 'Guess I belong here more than  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Been up north?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Knocked around for a couple of months  after the Army. You been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it ain't that good up there neither. Might  as well make it here. 'Course I ain't really  makin' it now. He gets up and gives her swing a forceful shove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, they can't get to you if you keep movin'! Josie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT YARD, DAWSON HOUSE
dialogues.text: It is raining. Duff and Josie dash up the path to the fro

dialogues.speaker: DAWSON PARLOR
dialogues.text: Duff and Josie barge in out of the rain and find themselv Reverend Dawson and a middle-aged white man - Superintend

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in, Josie. We're all through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy - this is Duff Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Johnson, our school superintendent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a friendly smile)  How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're courtin' the preacher's girl. Well,  just watch your step, boy, or he'll preach you  right into hell.  (to Reverend Dawson)  I'm counting on you, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't do for one of your people to sue at a  time like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his way out)  I'll talk to the Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll make the folks very happy. Johnson leaves. Reverend Dawson sits down in a rocker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to know how to talk to the white folks  these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess it's never been easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a changing time. Sit down, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He sits down opposite Reverend Dawson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like we'll be getting our new  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you all ain't sendin' them to the same  school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've got to go easy. We haven't had any  trouble in town for eight years, and we're not  going to have any now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't live without trouble, can you?  (he sees he is on  the wrong track)  Nice place you got here. Real nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the Lord's been pretty good to us. I  guess you're a church man, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Don't you believe in the Lord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, I do. But 'seems to me us colored folks do  a whole lot of church-goin'. It's the whites  that need it real bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think if you tried livin' in a town like this,  instead of running free and easy, you'd soon  change your tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  (rising)  Well, I guess we don't have much to say to each  other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And since we're talking, my wife and I don't  want you hanging around our daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that figures.  (he too stands up)  Kind of fits in with everything else, don't it!

dialogues.speaker: DAWSON PORCH
dialogues.text: Duff comes out. Josie joins him a moment later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's just like I figured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't belong here. I don't know what I' been thinkin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Duff - if you're free, I'm not working  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, baby. I'm goin' to Birmingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' to see my kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I ain't married. (leaving) Well, good-bye. COURTHOUSE SQUARE (Morning sunshine) A bus has pulled in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff is making his way down the aisle. To his surprise, h who is sitting at a window with an empty seat next to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  Well, what-do-you-know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Women're always followin' me 'round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going in to do my shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's just a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving on)  I'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Duff. No point running away from  coincidence. He sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, you must be crazy. The bus starts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is your boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't seen him in a couple of years.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEYWAY, BIRMINGHAM
dialogues.text: Duff is walking past crowded back-porches in a black sect music. He steps up onto one of the porches and knocks at the scr

dialogues.speaker: EFFIE'S PARLOR
dialogues.text: Through the screen door we see EFFIE SIMMS, a woman in he sitting on a chair and cradles a sleeping child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'You Effie Simms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously)  What d'you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you must be lookin' after my boy. I'm  Duff Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout time you showed. Door's open. Duff enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)  James Lee, you come in here and meet your daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Wilma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She done moved to Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't she goin' to take the boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got herself a husband now. They don' want  him 'round. And I tell you, man, I got no use  for him neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been sendin' her money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she never gave me none. Look, you better  find him a place pretty quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He's your boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't so sure of that. If I was, maybe I'd  feel different. Effie gives him a scornful look, puts down the child, and that leads into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)  James Lee - I said for you to come in here.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Two children are playing on the floor. James Lee is up on convertible. Duff appears beside Effie in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'you been, boy? James Lee looks at him, scared and silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Tell him. She returns to the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you something. He crouches down and holds out a toy. James Lee approache and withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: EFFIE'S PARLOR
dialogues.text: Effie is folding diapers. Duff comes out of the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Doctor says he could use some shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Look, I'll be sendin' you the money from  now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure he gets those shots. He looks back at the boy in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say your dad's 'round town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'That right? I thought he was up North.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People seen him 'round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's he at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Duff is walking through a black section of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff climbs to the top of the rickety wooden steps.

dialogues.speaker: WILL ANDERSON'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Duff's father, a big man in his fifties, is reclining on Duff appears in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'You Will Anderson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up, with  a faint grin)  Wouldn't have known you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't have known you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Heard you were in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanted a look at your old man, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's right. Will gets up and crosses the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Will pours whiskey into two glasses. Duff sees that Will' empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workin' a saw mill. (raising his glass) Here's to. A woman in her late thirties (LEE) comes in with a shoppi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby - want you to meet Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly)  Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my son! She turns and looks at Duff with a glimmer of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and have some coffee. (sitting down) I'm Lee. Sit down. He joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?! You mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting down)  Nothin'.  (to Duff)  She's all right. Wouldn't have made it without  her. Christ - haven't worked in eight months.  Right now, I'm waitin' for some insurance money.  And man, when I get it, I got plans to make me  some more.  (he gets up restlessly)  Let's get out'a here. This place gives me the  willies. (to Lee) You got some money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she knows what's coming)  Let's stay here, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)  What's the matter?! It's a celebration!

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Will, Lee, and Duff are standing at the bar. Will has bee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's this about a woman? You got woman  trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, I come to town with a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plannin' on getting married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Don't sound so sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, matter of fact, I done a lot of bangin'  'round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's how me an' your mother got started.  I'm tellin' you, boy, you ain't got a chance  without dough. They take it all away from you. He drains his glass and puts it down for Lee to refill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pour your own trouble, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother used to lay for her boss, boy. Did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so what's a girl supposed to do? Me not  workin' and her cleanin' house for a white man.  I'm tellin' you, boy, keep away from marriage.  Ya gotta stay light on your feet or you won't  make it. He puts his hand on Lee's bare arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she good in the hay? No point marryin' her  just to find out. Is there, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't quit it, Will, I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breaking my heart. (he grabs her neck  and shakes her) Got to see a man about a dog.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Duff and Lee are dancing. She looks at him with a touch o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him get you, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often does he get like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever he's got an edge on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been hitting it pretty hard. Got high  blood pressure, too. I guess it's hard on him,  having you around.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Will is back and drinking when Duff and Lee come off the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)  Well, what d'you think of her? Duff says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you somethin', boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good for a one-armed nigger, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you want anyhow? What you come and  bother me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boy, beat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the point. He leaves money on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back some other time, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. Good luck. DOWNTOWN STREET (Night) Duff is walking, lost in thought. INT. BUS DEPOT (Night) Josie enters with her purchases. She joins Duff at the sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved to see her)  I thought you wasn't comin'. She sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to off-screen waitress)  I'll have some coffee, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I been thinkin' - how 'bout us gettin'  married? Josie is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing for time)  What d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what I said. Don't look so scared. The waitress puts down a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Duff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, baby - I don't know 'bout you, but it's  the right thing for me. I just know it is. So,  what d'you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't push me, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wouldn't be no picnic for you. I ain't  exactly housebroken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't mean nothin' to me. That's all over. (after a moment) Hell, baby - I'm askin' you to marry me. I  guess you want a big scene, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But a small one. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yes, huh? INT. BUNK CAR (Day) Frankie is looking scornfully at Duff, who is lying on hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be a monkey's kid sister! What d'you want  to do a thing like that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Musta knocked her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you gonna get out of it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)  A whole lot, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)  Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a home, for one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna sit at home the rest of your life?  Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's better than windin' up like a bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively)  What 'you signifyin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't thinkin' about you, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ol' Doris sure goin' to miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give him a couple of months. A girl like  that, she don't know any tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what Doris told me? She say: That  Duff's a nice guy. Wouldn't even charge him  nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you'll be quittin' the railroad, huh,  man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you must be plumb outa your mind! You'll  be makin' twen'y bucks a week, if you're lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie is next to Duff. They are driving past a row of sma in the black section of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn here. There it is! They stop in front of a house. It is barely larger than a

dialogues.speaker: DILAPIDATED LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Duff and Jose come in. The room is full of abandoned, bro the ceiling and wallpaper hang down in strips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to know them. They've gone North.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh)  I can see why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what d'you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay with me, baby. But how' you goin' to  like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be fine when we get done with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff is looking out through the broken pane of glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORING HOUSE, SEEN FROM WINDOW
dialogues.text: A woman is putting laundry into a washing machine on the children are all around her and in the yard below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie has stopped next to Duff and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Bessie Hall. Barney works at the mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Josie removes a shard of glass from the window; a larger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watch out! Guess you want a house full of  pickaninnies too, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call them that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right with me. Always liked kids. He moves to the rear of the room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Josie turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively)  What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could live with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just see how the two of us make out  first, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff and Josie are getting married. Duff is waiting near section hands are seated on one side of the aisle, Josie' on the other. The gospel piano segues into the wedding ma down the aisle by herself. She joins Duff and they step f Reverend Dawson. DUFF AND JOSIE'S BEDROOM (Early morning)  Josie lies in bed with closed eyes. She hears Duff move a is dressed for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, baby. He sits down beside her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff is in the rear seat with his new neighbor, Barney.  Joe, a millhand, sits next to the driver in front. He tur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to get up in the morning, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  That's right. How' you doin', Barney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not given to saying much)  Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car drives up and Joe leans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Willie! Willie, a big man, has been fixing his front step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on - we're late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his time)  Yazzuh, Boss - ah's comin' as fast as ah can. He picks up his lunch box and shuffles toward the car, St

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)  Get in the car, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie climbs in next to Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How' you doing, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (to the driver) Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Jethro - take us to the plant.  And hurry, boy - ah's got a heavy day. The driver backs up fast, jerking the passengers forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah tells you, man - you give these niggers a  machine and they go stark-ravin' wild! Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff is among the mill hands punching in on the time cloc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off screen)  You new here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MILL YARD
dialogues.text: Duff and two other men are working on top of a pile of lu A white supervisor on a forklift has been watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)  Hey, Jack! Duff doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, boy - I'm talkin' to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment)  Name's Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genially)  Looks like you're doin' a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say much, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so you do your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mill hands are on their lunch break. The only white m looking at Duff with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I bet those black girls really go for you,  huh? That's the best-lookin' colored girl in  town. Duff is eating and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Still on your honeymoon,  huh? Just like you, Barney. 'Been on your  honeymoon for twen'y years, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously)  Yeah. The white mill hand helps himself to a piece of Barney's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many kids you got now, Barney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating the pie)  Hmmm - she can cook,too. Man, it's no wonder you  'been draggin' your tail on the job. You 'been  doin' your best work at home. He notices that Duff's face is set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)  What's the matter, boy? Never smile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll smile when it's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it wasn't funny, huh? Well, I thought it was.  What d'you say, Barney? Wasn't it funny?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  (to the others)  What d'you say, boys? Wasn't it funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duff)  Trouble with you, boy, you ain't got no sense  of humor. Ought to smile more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You' new here, man!  (he gets up to leave)  See you, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duff after a moment)  You know, man, that guy was trying to be  friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't my idea of friendliness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to watch yourself pretty close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you want to get along, act the nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell. You know, if you fellows stuck  together 'stead of letting them walk all over  you, they might not try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell they wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They been doin' it all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's time you stopped letting them. Jesse, a heavy-set man who has been silent till now, stan Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you sound like a trouble man. EXT. DUFF AND JOSIE'S HOUSE (Dusk) The lights are on inside.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF AND JOSIE'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Duff is finishing his supper at the table. Josie is at th coffee. She puts a piece of pie in front of him. He drink the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use the glass, honey. That's what it's for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's so. She returns to the stove. Duff picks up the pie and sniff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells like something crawled in there and died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently)  Oh really? I thought it was pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, baby. He gets her to sit on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you cook is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff - you know those women you used to know-- He forks a bite of pie into her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her mouth full)  Am I as good as they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinking)  Hmmm - good coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, you're the best thing that ever happened  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still didn't answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you don't know I can't tell you. She elbows him in the stomach. He laughs. BACKYARD (Night) Duff is helping Josie take in the wash. Music from Barney

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how to box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My kids want me to teach them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Come on. Put 'em up! She assumes the posture of a boxer. Duff laughs and adjus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like so. There you go. Okay, hit me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on - hit me! She does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh! My, oh my! They spar - briefly in sync with the music. She goes afte arms. The music is turned off abruptly and we hear Bessie's rai out on the porch of her house, yelling at Barney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave me alone! You can sit out here all  night. I don't care what you do! You're no good  around the house anyway. Barney remains silent. Duff and Josie exchange a look. DUFF AND JOSIE'S BEDROOM (Night) They are in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely)  It sure scares you, a guy like that - settin'  out on his porch, doin' nothin'. I seen hundreds of them - all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's never done a thing for any of them. He touches her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very happy, Duff. How about you? He smiles. Josie gets up and slips out of her nightgown. Her body me darkness. DUFF AND JOSIE'S LIVING ROOM (Evening) The place has been painted and simply furnished. Josie has made dinner for the section hands. Pop is the o eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure done a great job, Mrs. Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but you haven't eaten very much. How  about it, Frankie? I bet you could eat some  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duff)  How's that job comin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it ain't the railroad. Those guys are  scared. Guess they've never known nothin' but  takin' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edge)  They all got families to support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly)  Yeah. That's right, Jocko.  (to the others)  Those white guys sure shoot up at you like a  yeast cake if you just cock an eye at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)  I guess you'll be making' some changes 'round  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  What's eatin' you, Jocko?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. I just figure you were the right man  for the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changing the subject)  I guess you'll all keep workin' together, won't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck, no. They're shippin' us all over the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wan' 'em, there's some expert dishwashers  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. My kitchen's too small. Riddick gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fellows - let's give the folks some  privacy.

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: The men, on their way out, shake hands with Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Got a good thing, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Pop.  (shaking Riddick's hand)  'See you before you take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Jocko. BATHROOM (Night) Duff is washing his face at the sink. Josie comes up behi her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff. He turns to her. Instead of speaking, she turns her back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My back itches. He scratches her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to have a baby, Duff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look so scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You jivin' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't come around. Duff is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that something?! (recovering) That's just fine, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be all right. He kisses her and sits down on the rim of the bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, we sure hit the jackpot fast around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your boy?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: How come you keep askin'?

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: I keep thinking about him.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Well, he ain't mine, so skip it. She gargles. Duff moves over to her with a grin and puts

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Baby, we're goin' to put a whole lot of little  kids into this world. Hell, we'll swamp 'em.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM, MILL
dialogues.text: The men are done for the day. Duff is putting on his shir the shower.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Hell, if they can do it in Birmingham - and  that's a mean town, we oughta do something here. Willie says nothing. His eyes are on a white supervisor, the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: 'You Duff Anderson?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: I hear you're tryin' to organize this place!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talkin' about.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: That's no way to talk, boy. Now we had one of  them union men 'round here coupla years ago.  Stirred up a lot of trouble. They're always  after you colored boys.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I still don't know what you're talkin' about.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: You a union man?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Used to be. On the railroad.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Well, this ain't the railroad. Now  what's all this talk about stickin' together?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Well, what d'you know?! He looks over at the other men. They avoid his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Look, boy, we got a smooth operation here, and  I aim to keep it that way. Now I got an idea  you're plannin' trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: No. You got the wrong idea.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: All right, then. All I want you to do is tell  these boys here you didn't mean what you said about stickin' together an' all. Duff says nothing. The mill hands watch him silently.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Want to keep your job, boy?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: What d'you think?

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Then do like I said. (to the men) Men - this boy here's got something to tell  you-all. (to Duff) Well, how about it? Duff looks at the supervisor in silence, fully aware that fired. He turns and opens his locker.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Boy, you're actin' like a nigger with no sense.  All right, go down' the office and get your pay.  Tell them you're through.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF'S CAR
dialogues.text: He is driving past Josie's school and slows down. The kid yard but Josie is not in sight. He accelerates, his face DUFF AND JOSIE'S BEDROOM (Night) Josie is correcting papers on the bed. Duff is at the man cat. He puts a small box over its head. The cat cries out clumsily, trying to free itself.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Don't, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. He sits down. Josie comes over and sits on the arm of the

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I'm jumpy, that's all. She runs her hand through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Well, you've had quite a day. He brushes her off:

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I don't like bein' mothered. When she touches him again, he jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Jesus, baby -- leave me alone, will ya? He flings himself down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (sitting down beside him)  Don't deny me, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Hell, baby - I met this beautiful chick and  she's just dyin' for me, okay? She takes him by the shoulders and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Don't be so silly. Duff laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. But just how're we goin' to make out? I  got to get me a job.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Pay is so damn low. I don't want my kids to  grow up like Barney's.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: They won't.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, baby, maybe we better get out  of here.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (gravely)  We can always do that, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, I know. I'm not really thinkin'  about it. Anyway, don't want those white guys  laughin' up their sleeve at me when they see  me pull out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff waits outside the open window, while the white man i his job application.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can use you. Ever work a saw mill?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE
dialogues.text: Where was that?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (after a moment's hesitation)  Walker and Williams.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE
dialogues.text: What did you say your name is?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Anderson. The man checks for Duff's name on a list.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE
dialogues.text: (turning to Duff)  Sorry, boy, there ain't nothin' here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff is sitting at the lunch counter. Joe, the mill hand,

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to the waitress)  Hello, Frances. He sits down next to Duff.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How 'you doin' man?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (non-committal)  Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (to Frances)  Cup of coffee.  (to Duff)  I 'been meanin' to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know, over at the mill, there's just one guy  that talked. It's kinda late to say it, but we  shoulda acted different. The waitress brings his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Been over to the other mill?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, I been there.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's just that we're not used to seein' anyone  stand up 'round here. Kinda took us by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff is at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Well, if you tried the mills, there ain't no  other industry 'round here.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: How 'bout that furniture plant?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (with a laugh)  Man, the darkest thing they got in there is  Coca-Cola.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Now, if you want to work like a real nigger,  you can always go out and chop cotton.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (grimly)  They done that too long in my family.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: They pay you three bucks a day an' all the  cotton you can eat. Duff laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL LOBBY
dialogues.text: Duff faces the white manager, who is behind the registrat

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I might have something for you, if you  want to put on a uniform. Duff looks over at the one black man in the lobby - a uni emptying ashtrays.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: What's the pay?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Pay's ten dollars a week, plus tips and lunch.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I see. Ain't for me, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white proprietor has rung up the order for an elderly

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETOR
dialogues.text: Now what about soap?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I got enough.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETOR
dialogues.text: (insisting)  I got a good buy on soap. You go on over there  an' take a look!  (urging her on)  Right over there. The woman goes over to look at the soap. The proprietor t

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETOR
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I'm lookin' for work.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETOR
dialogues.text: I got a boy. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is driving through town at a fast clip. The car rattle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff and clientele are black. Duff enters and sits down close to Josie, who is having h

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Don't ask, baby - huh! (lowering his voice) How much money you got with you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: About ten dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Water pump's busted. I don't know if it's worth  fixin', but I need that car.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: You can have what I've got. It's right there. Duff opens her pocketbook, embarrassed by the women watch

dialogues.speaker: FLAT BED TRUCK
dialogues.text: It rattles over a country road between cotton fields. Duf field hands on the open flatbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white foreman is up on the loading platform. He addre field hands looking for work.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Startin' tomorrow mornin', we got work for  fifteen hands. All we're gonna pay is two-fifty  a day. Can't pay you the three 'cause ain't  gonna be much of a crop this year. Now you all  who want to work, step up and we'll take your  name. Duff is among the few who leave. The others surge closer ready to work for any wage. DUFF AND JOSIE'S PORCH (Night) Josie is sewing on the porch. Duff is in the yard a few f back of an axe to hammer loose nails into an old chair.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: It's not as hard on a girl. They're not afraid  of us. Duff says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: You know - we do have enough money. Especially  now.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (grimly)  Sure, baby. 'Fact, I don't ever have to work no  more. When that baby comes, I can just stay  home and send you back to school. How about  that?

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (after a moment)  I could work even after the baby comes. A few  hours a week, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: What the hell could you do?

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Day work.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: 'You kiddin'? You ain't goin' to no white home.  I seen the way they look at you when you go  down the street. He jumps up and raises the axe--

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: No point fixin' it!

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (frightened)  What're you going to do? He smashes the axe into the chair.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (jumping up)  Don't do that!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Watch out! He smashes the chair to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (throwing down the axe)  Good kindlin'! He turns to Josie. She is looking at him, deeply upset.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: What's bitin' you now!? She turns away. He jumps up onto the porch and grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: You heard me!

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: I can't stand to see you like that. I know you  can't help it.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (darkly)  Stop bein' so damn understandin'. DUFF AND JOSIE'S LIVING ROOM (Day) Duff is on the sofa, looking up at Reverend Dawson.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: I know just how you feel, son. But believe me,  you're going about it the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Don't look like there's a right way.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: Well, you have to be reasonable. Now they say  you're a troublemaker. That's no good. Use a  little psychology. Make 'em think you're going  along - and get what you want.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: It ain't in me.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: You'll be in trouble, son. (after a moment)  Now just how do you intend to support your  family?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I guess I'll rob a bank.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: Don't you get smart with me, boy. We hear a dish break.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Josie is on the floor, picking up pieces of broken glass.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: Maybe you ought to move. You'd be a lot better  off in the North.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: So I been told.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: It's for your own good.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?  (he gets up)  Seems to me, Reverend, you' more concerned  'bout your good. Guess it looks kind 'a bad,  havin' me for a son-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: You can be cocky now, boy. But you won't make  it. You won't last. I just feel sorry for Josie.  I knew it wouldn't work out.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Well, at least she ain't married to no white  man's nigger! You been stoopin' so long,  Reverend, you don't even know how to stand  straight no more. You' just half a man!

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Josie has cut her finger on the glass. She is weeping sil

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Reverend Dawson turns to leave. His sense of calm superio

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: (at the door)  Maybe I could talk to Bud Ellis. He might have a  job for you at his filling station.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAWSON
dialogues.text: I'll be seeing you. Josie has come into the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (gravely)  'Bye, Dad. DUFF AND JOSIE'S BEDROOM (Night) Duff watches Josie. She is sitting at her dressing table.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: How come you don't hate their guts?

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I guess I'm not afraid of them.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: You were plenty scared that night in the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Just of getting hurt. They can't touch me  inside.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Like hell they can't. (he gets up) They can reach right in with their damn white  hands and turn you off and on.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Not if you see them for what they are, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (exploding)  Jesus, baby, you're so full of talk! Well, you  ain't never really been a nigger, have you -  livin' like that in your father's house! So  just shut your mouth. EXT. GAS STATION (Night) Duff finishes pumping gas into Joe's car.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: That's two bucks, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (paying)  Why don't you come over for a beer when you get  through?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Okay, I will. Brad Ellis, the white owner of the service station, comes

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Hey, Duff! Run the truck down Holly Road.  There's a guy in the ditch. CAB OF TOW TRUCK (Night) Duff is driving along a wooded country road. Shreds of fo headlights. A ditched car comes into view, its front end crushed agai white man stands beside it, waving to Duff with a flashli and backs up to the car.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: The owner comes toward him eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Sure glad to see you, boy. Duff gets out of the tow truck to inspect the damaged car him, nervous and garrulous.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Guess I was kinda lucky, huh? My wife's going to  give me hell. Duff lowers the hoist on the truck.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: (anxiously)  How you doin', boy?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Okay. He gets under the car to attach the chain.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Want me to hold the light for you?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Just tryin' to be helpful. He continues talking, though Duff can't hear him.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Most folks around here got no use for nigrahs.  Got to understand them, that's all. How you  doin', boy?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (emerging from under the car)  Okay. The owner tests the rig with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Seems a little loose!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (with a grin)  She'll do. He starts raising the car.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: She ain't comin' up even! Duff ignores him. The chain slips and the car drops to the ground with a ba

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: (jumping back)  Jesus, I told you to watch it!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Sorry. He gets back under the car.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: That's the trouble with you boys! Don't listen  when a man tells you something.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: She don't look no worse to me.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Don't do her no good to get banged like that.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (under the car)  Don't do her no good to go into a tree.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: (enraged)  What did you say, boy?!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I said, she's in great shape.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: I heard you! Now 'stead of bein' smart, you just  get that car out of here! GAS STATION (Night) Duff is changing a tire outside the repair bay. A car shoots out of the dark with its horn blaring, and s at the pump. Brad Ellis steps up to the driver.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Can I help you? The driver is the white mill hand who gave Duff a hard ti

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (indicating Duff)  Like some service from that boy there. Like the  way he takes care of us. ELLIS Okay. Duff has come over. He is aware of impending trouble. One car is the owner of the ditched vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Fill her up?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: No, boy. Thirty-eight cents worth of gas. And  watch you don't make it thirty-nine. Duff starts the pump.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Didn't hear you say "Yessir!" Don't they say  "Yessir" where you come from? Duff finishes pumping and puts the nozzle back onto the p

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Boy - you hear me?!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: That'll be thirty-eight cents.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, nigger - you must think you're white!  Who d'you think you are - king of Harlem?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WHITE
dialogues.text: How 'bout this windshield, boy? Like a little  service. Duff takes a moment before moving to the windshield and w inside the car watch him through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD WHITE
dialogues.text: Hell, they're getting' too big for their  britches.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WHITE
dialogues.text: Yeah, his wife's the same way, struttin' through  town like she owns the place - shakin' that  little rear end.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD WHITE
dialogues.text: It's all that education they're getting.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Real cool, ain't he! Just like we're not here. Duff moves over to the driver.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: That'll be thirty-eight cents.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: You in a big hurry, boy?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WHITE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's tryin' to get home!

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Bet she's pretty hot, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (very tense)  You watch your mouth, man! The driver has finally found a way of getting to Duff and his face.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: I bet she's a sly little nigger, that girl.  Wouldn't mind a piece of her myself!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: All right, you get out of here, man!

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (exploding)  Who're you tellin' to get, boy?! You watch it,  or there'll be some dyin' done 'round here!

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: That dyin's gonna be done two ways. He steps away from the car, a hand on the rear pocket whe knife. In the backseat, the owner of the ditched car looks nervo

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Let's go, Al. He ain't worth it.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (turning on him)  Now you stay out of it! Brad Ellis has come over.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: You better get rid of this white-eyed nigger!

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: (to Duff)  What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Never mind! You keep him workin' here and this  place won't be around. And I ain't kiddin'! He guns the engine and shoots out of the service station Duff looks at Ellis, whose next move is predictable, and run a water hose over the back of his neck. Ellis stops next to him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Guess we got trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (blowing up)  You ain't got none, Mister!

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (tossing down the hose)  Don't tell me. I know. DUFF AND JOSIE'S LIVING ROOM (Night) Duff enters. Josie comes out of the bedroom in her nightgown. She has

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: I called the gas station. I've been worried. Duff slumps down on the sofa, utterly discouraged.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Hell, if they don't blow up his place, they'll  get him some other way. Don't make no difference  no-how.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (anxiously)  What d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Nothin. Quit lookin' at me like that! He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: (approaching him)  Duff, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Well, that don't do me one bit of good! She touches him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Duff - let's go to bed. He gives her a sudden, violent shove. It sends her sprawl She picks herself up, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I never should have married you in the first  place. He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Ain't you goin' to say something?

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: There's nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Well, that'll be the first time. He leaves the room. DUFF AND JOSIE'S BEDROOM (Night) Duff is packing his things. Josie is on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Where're you going to go?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: When I get set, I'll send for you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: I don't think that'll happen.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: You'll be better off without me. I ain't fit to  live with no more. It's just like a lynchin'.  Maybe they don't use a knife on you, but they  got other ways.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: You're not a man because of a job, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: You don' know nothin' 'bout it, baby. Nothin'!  And don't kid yourself - you did your bit. He closes his bag.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Duff--

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (at the door)  Like I said, baby - I'll write you. INT. DUFF'S CAR (Dawn) He is driving across a bridge into Birmingham.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNTOWN STREET
dialogues.text: Duff stands on a deserted corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff climbs up to Will Anderson's room.

dialogues.speaker: WILL'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Will is sitting at the table in a drunken stupor. There i door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It's your son. Duff enters.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: My son? I ain't got no son. You Duff?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Beat it! He gets up and staggers toward Duff

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Don't smell so good, huh?  Must'a broken some records. He pushes Duff away and pours himself a glass of whiskey. shaking.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: (trying to restrain him)  Come on, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Nothing you can do. Been like this for days.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Got no use for nobody. He raises the glass to his mouth, but drops it and puts h of his head.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: What is it? What's the matter? Lee grabs Will and pushes him onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (at the end of her rope)  Now you lay down and get some sleep! Will grabs her blindly and pulls her down onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (freeing herself, furious)  You let go! She starts picking up the broken glass. Will sits up agai

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Now you stay put!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (leaving the bed)  I ain't drunk, honey.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Like hell you ain't! He sits down at the table and touches the back of his hea

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Got a thick feelin' here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What's the matter now?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Better now. (closing his eyes) Where 'you at?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (concerned)  Right here. She puts her hand on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Couldn't get the words out before.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Better get him to a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you to beat it - huh?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (taking Will's arm)  Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Anything you say, baby. With Duff's help, Lee raises Will out of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff has helped Lee get Will into the backseat of his car Through the window we see him grope blindly for Lee's bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff, in the driver's seat, is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (off-screen)  Duff. Duff turns to her. Will's head is in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He stopped breathin'. Duff stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The undertaker sits down behind his desk. He lays out Wil other belongings for Duff and Lee, who are standing in fr

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: We thought you might want these.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: Would you like me to say anything tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Guess so.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: Have anything in mind?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: No. What you usually say, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: Where was your father born?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I don't know. He looks at Lee. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: His profession?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Well, he worked around.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: And his age?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: I don't know. Forty-eight, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: Any other family?

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: No. Just me. (he includes Lee) Me an' her.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: Well, I guess that's all till tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DUFF
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks very much.

dialogues.speaker: URBAN CEMETERY, BIRMINGHAM
dialogues.text: The mechanical arm of a backhoe opens up a new grave. Duff and Lee walk away from the burial site. The camera m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you going to do? Duff says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to come up the house? You can stay there  till you get on your feet. There's no point  paying a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that I hate empty rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what're you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll make me some trouble in that town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going back, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll run you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'you gonna live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can always chop cotton if I have to. (he stops) If you want a ride, I'll take you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I'll take the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be too hard on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I'm just like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he wasn't much of a father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Duff. She walks away. BIRMINGHAM ALLEYWAY (Night) From the interior of Duff's car we see Duff come out of E carrying James Lee through the rain. He deposits the scar front seat and gets in on the driver's side. James Lee sh from Duff as the seat allows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a kindly grin)  That window's broke, boy. You stay over there,  you're gonna get awful wet. INT. MOVING CAR (Dawn) The sun is coming up through the trees. James Lee is asle

dialogues.speaker: DUFF AND JOSIE'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Duff brings in the sleeping boy and puts him down on the to get his belongings. Josie has woken up and comes in from the bedroom in her n James Lee and leans over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)  Hi. James Lee opens his eyes. Josie hears Duff enter and turns to him. They come togeth other for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't gonna be easy, baby - but it's gonna be  all right. Josie is weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby I feel so free inside.
